text: To protect the planet, we can all do our
label: H1

text: part
label: H1

text: Students  pick  up  non-biodegradable
label: BODY

text: plastics  from  the  Saint  Monica
label: BODY

text: University  Campus,  Cameroon.  (Photo
label: BODY

text: courtesy  Gabila  Franklin  Neba.)
label: BODY

text: Did you know small changes in your daily routines can make a huge difference to your health, the
label: BODY

text: health of your neighbors and the future of the planet? Choose from among these simple steps and
label: BODY

text: start today.
label: BODY

text: Join #YALIGoesGreen this month. Learn how to get involved at yali.state.gov/climate.
label: BODY

text: When you run errands or travel …
label: H3

text: • Walk or ride a bike.
label: BODY

text: • Take public transportation.
label: BODY

text: • Organize errands into one trip.
label: BODY

text: • When driving, accelerate gradually and drive at lower speeds.
label: BODY

text: • Drive less, particularly on days with unhealthy air.
label: BODY

text: When you are at home …
label: H3

text: What we do at home makes a big impact on air quality. Consuming less energy helps reduce air
label: BODY

text: pollution, as does choosing sustainable, recyclable products. Limit use of chemicals that contribute
label: BODY

text: to smog.
label: BODY

text: Did you know that detergents, cleaning compounds, glues, polishes and even cosmetics, perfume
label: BODY

text: and deodorants contribute to smog? Such items contain volatile chemicals that evaporate readily.
label: BODY

text: When the sun shines, they combine with other pollutants to form ozone, a primary component of
label: BODY

text: smog that is bad for our health.
label: BODY

text: • Turn the lights off when you leave a room.
label: BODY

text: • Replace energy-hungry incandescent lights with energy-saving CFLs or LEDs.
label: BODY

text: • If alternative energy sources such as solar or wind are available, use them.
label: BODY

text: • Recycle paper, plastic and organic materials.
label: BODY

text: • Use nonpolluting stoves. Avoid using kerosene to cook, heat or provide light.
label: BODY

text: • Choose products made from recycled materials or sustainable sources such as bamboo, hemp and
label: BODY

text: coconut fiber.
label: BODY

text: • Use durable, reusable shopping bags, not disposable plastic bags.
label: BODY

text: • Paint with a brush instead of a sprayer.
label: BODY

text: • Store all solvents in airtight containers.
label: BODY

text: • Eliminate use of toxic chemicals at home; opt for natural substitutes.
label: BODY

text: • Plant a tree to help purify the air.
label: BODY

text: When you are at work …
label: H3

text: • Use natural light during the day.
label: BODY

text: • Work from home if possible.
label: BODY

text: • If you work in an office, start a recycling program. Print and photocopy on both sides of paper, and
label: BODY

text: only print when necessary.
label: BODY

text: • Turn off office equipment (i.e., computers, printers and fax machines) after hours.
label: BODY

text: When you are in your community …
label: H3

text: • Support efforts to “green” the neighborhood.
label: BODY

text: • Start an environmental program yourself.
label: BODY

text: • Let your elected representatives know you support action for cleaner air.
label: BODY

text: Adapted from the California Air Resources Board’s “Simple Solutions to Help Reduce Air Pollution.”
label: BODY

text: The Promise of Wind Power
label: H1

text: Join #YALIGoesGreen this month. Learn how to get involved at yali.state.gov/climate
label: BODY

text: Solar,  biofuels  and  hydropower  are  among  the  energy  sources  the  United  States  has  been
label: BODY

text: developing aggressively since President Obama began the transition to a clean energy economy with
label: BODY

text: his Climate Action Plan.
label: BODY

text: Wind, an energy technology with a long history, is another green power source with great potential.
label: BODY

text: A new report from the U.S. Energy Department analyzes how the nation might increase its use of
label: BODY

text: wind power.
label: BODY

text: Many African nations are also investing in wind power, which can, as the U.S. report says, “address
label: BODY

text: key societal challenges such as climate change, air quality and public health, and water scarcity.”
label: BODY

text: The Lake Turkana Wind Power Project in the north-east of Kenya aims to produce 20 percent of the
label: BODY

text: country’s electricity generating capacity when it comes online in 2016.
label: BODY

text: Ayitepa Wind Farm the east coast of Ghana and is also slated to come online in 2016 and promises to
label: BODY

text: generate 10 percent of the country’s generating capacity.
label: BODY

text: Issued in May, the almost-300-page report says the United States has tripled its use of wind power
label: BODY

text: since 2008. Wind supplies 4.5 percent of the nation’s electricity today, and the nation could set a
label: BODY

text: realistic plan to meet 10 percent of the electricity demand in 2020, 20 percent in 2030, and 35
label: BODY

text: percent in 2050.
label: BODY

text: If the nation does reach that 2050 target, the report calculates considerable benefits:
label: BODY

text: The nation’s total electric bill would be 3 percent lower.
label: BODY

text: Greenhouse gas emissions would drop by 14 percent.
label: BODY

text: Using less fossil fuel would reduce pollutants such as sulfur dioxides, nitrogen oxides and
label: BODY

text: particulate matter.
label: BODY

text: Pollution-related deaths would be reduced by almost 22,000 between 2013 and 2050.
label: BODY

text: The use of water would go down 23 percent as the nation became less dependent on fossil-fuel
label: BODY

text: power plants, which use water as a cooling agent.
label: BODY

text: Beyond these calculable benefits, Wind Vision predicts adoption of more wind power also would put
label: BODY

text: downward price pressure on fossil fuels in energy markets, saving consumers $280 billion.
label: BODY

text: So if wind will give electricity for less money with less pollution, maybe wind power should be in
label: BODY

text: your future too.
label: BODY

text: Telling Your Story Visually on Social
label: H1

text: Media
label: H1

text: Credit: Climate Action Campaign
label: BODY

text: When you’re crafting a message on social media, creating a narrative is important to its success.
label: BODY

text: Tara McMahon is the digital creative director at Climate Action Campaign, where she focuses on
label: BODY

text: telling the story of climate change and finding innovative ways to convey the detailed science of
label: BODY

text: climate change.
label: BODY

text: “Given the nature of platforms like Facebook and Twitter,” said McMahon, “images and graphics
label: BODY

text: offer an important opportunity to engage the reader in your story.”
label: BODY

text: We asked McMahon to offer the YALI Network her tips for incorporating compelling visuals into
label: BODY

text: online campaigns.
label: BODY

text: 1. Create a mini-campaign “brand” for a set of visuals.
label: BODY

text: Using consistent fonts, colors and design elements helps drive the overarching message visually.
label: BODY

text: 2. Pick the best approach for telling your story.
label: BODY

text: Info graphics are helpful for distilling finds in reports, photos are best for highlighting real-life
label: BODY

text: impacts, and quotes and graphics are good for elevating direct stories.
label: BODY

text: 3. Use your resources!
label: BODY

text: The Internet is full of free and low-cost resources: templates for infographics, free fonts, color
label: BODY

text: palette generations, Creative Commons photos and more.
label: BODY

text: 4. Think of visuals as a companion to your messaging.
label: BODY

text: For example, visuals can help tell a story about real-world local impacts of a global problem like
label: BODY

text: climate change. It’s important to start with a strong message you’re looking to convey. Then visuals
label: BODY

text: help give more context so you can craft a story that will really resonate with the viewer.
label: BODY

text: 5. Be creative!
label: BODY

text: Trying new things is the best way to determine what works with your audience. Test out using two
label: BODY

text: different types of visuals that convey the same story and see which one engages people the most.
label: BODY

text: Women’s Situation Rooms: Women
label: H1

text: Protecting Women’s Voting Rights
label: H1

text: Liberians celebrate the inauguration of
label: BODY

text: President
label: BODY

text: Ellen
label: BODY

text: Johnson-Sirleaf.
label: BODY

text: Liberia’s 2011 election was the first to use a
label: BODY

text: Women’s Situation Room. (©AP Images)
label: BODY

text: While Nigerians went to the polls in March 2015 for what would prove to be historic elections, 40
label: BODY

text: young people in Abuja, mostly women, answered phones around the clock, fielding calls about
label: BODY

text: outbreaks of violence and voter suppression.
label: BODY

text: Meanwhile, 300 female election monitors observed polls in 10 targeted Nigerian states, reporting
label: BODY

text: irregularities back to Abuja. There, a team of eight eminent women from Nigeria, Liberia, Sierra
label: BODY

text: Leone and Senegal worked with political parties and religious groups to address threats of violence
label: BODY

text: against women voters and women candidates as they happened.
label: BODY

text: Welcome to the Women’s Situation Room. Nigeria’s election was the most recent African election to
label: BODY

text: benefit from a four-year-old idea that’s been spreading throughout the continent. Originated during
label: BODY

text: the  2011  presidential  and  legislative  elections  in  Liberia  to  promote  women’s  leadership
label: BODY

text: development, the Women’s Situation Room model has been replicated in Senegal, Sierra Leone, Mali
label: BODY

text: and Guinea-Bissau.
label: BODY

text: Participants  in  Nigeria’s  Women’s
label: BODY

text: Situation Room during the March 2015
label: BODY

text: elections. (Courtesy U.S. Embassy Nigeria)
label: BODY

text: Studies show that women and children are the most likely to be affected by election violence,
label: BODY

text: including efforts to prevent women from exercising their right to vote. Women’s Situation Rooms
label: BODY

text: employ women and youth to ensure access to the polls.
label: BODY

text: Among the desks in Nigeria’s Women’s Situation Room was one staffed with police representatives
label: BODY

text: and  another  with  representatives  from  Nigeria’s  Independent  Electoral  Commission,  allowing
label: BODY

text: immediate response to outbreaks of violence and incidents of voter exclusion.
label: BODY

text: “If a situation happens in the field and we want answers from the police — like violence erupted in a
label: BODY

text: certain state while [women] were taking part in the election — we respond by finding the particular
label: BODY

text: arm of government, INEC or police, to tackle the situation. If they’re in the room, it’s of course
label: BODY

text: easier and faster,” Turrie Akerele Ismael, Nigeria’s solicitor-general and one of the situation room’s
label: BODY

text: eminent women, reported to U.N. Women.
label: BODY

text: “Women and youth play an active role in sustaining peace before, during and after the elections,”
label: BODY

text: said  Sylvie  Ndongmo  of  the  Women’s  International  League  for  Peace  and  Freedom,  which
label: BODY

text: coordinated the Women’s Situation Room for the Nigerian election. When civic groups work with
label: BODY

text: governmental agencies to reduce threats to voters and candidates, said Ndongmo, “the threat of
label: BODY

text: electoral violence becomes an opportunity for promoting sustainable peace and democracy.”
label: BODY

text: #YALIVotes: “Give Young People the
label: H1

text: Feeling They’re Cared About”
label: H1

text: (Kendra Helmer/USAID)
label: BODY

text: Ako Essan Emile has seen what happens when elections go bad. He was attending a university in
label: BODY

text: Côte d’Ivoire’s city of Abidjan when violence broke out in the wake of the disputed 2010 election.
label: BODY

text: In the years since then, he’s thought a lot about what it takes to bring free and fair elections to his
label: BODY

text: country. “Much has to be done to build trust between young people and politicians,” Ako said. “YALI
label: BODY

text: Network members in Côte d’Ivoire have started creating a platform for young people to interact with
label: BODY

text: political leaders.”
label: BODY

text: He contrasted his experience as a Mandela Washington Fellow with his experience with politicians
label: BODY

text: at home. “We came to the United States in August and we had the opportunity to talk to President
label: BODY

text: Obama. We’d never had this opportunity in our country.”
label: BODY

text: Ako sees open communication between candidates and the people they hope to represent as an
label: BODY

text: important basis for better elections and better leadership. “Most leaders don’t consider young
label: BODY

text: people when making their strategies. They just use young people as bait to attract other young
label: BODY

text: people.”
label: BODY

text: Ako is the managing director of Radio Arc-en-ciel, a community-based station in the urban area of
label: BODY

text: Abobo. In the months leading up to the October election, Radio Arc-en-ciel hosted roundtable
label: BODY

text: discussions to give a voice to one of the country’s largest (1.5 million) and least-represented
label: BODY

text: communities and also to inform Abobo’s residents.
label: BODY

text: “One of the key issues is lack of education about the electoral process,” Ako said. “No accurate
label: BODY

text: information is given, and if a politician comes into a community he will talk to the population
label: BODY

text: according to his point of view, but not in a balanced way. People can be misled and it can cause
label: BODY

text: conflict.”
label: BODY

text: Ako Essan Emile (right) in the Radio
label: BODY

text: Arc-en-ciel studio in September 2015.
label: BODY

text: (Kendra Helmer/USAID)
label: BODY

text: In addition to the roundtable radio shows, Radio Arc-en-ciel hosted events that balanced live music
label: BODY

text: with information. “We invited experts to come in and explain the electoral code to the population. If
label: BODY

text: they know the electoral code, they will be able to monitor whether the election is going the right way
label: BODY

text: or the wrong way. If someone doesn’t have accurate information they can feel that fraud is going on,
label: BODY

text: and then one rumor will come out and spark into violence and escalate into bloodshed.”
label: BODY

text: With elections upcoming in Burkina Faso, Benin, Niger and Uganda, Ako pointed to things that
label: BODY

text: worked well in Côte d’Ivoire in keeping the elections nonviolent and fair. “During our election, young
label: BODY

text: people  were  on  the  ground  as  observers  and  were  reporting  live.  Some  other  civil  society
label: BODY

text: organizations copied this example, so there were many young people spread around Côte d’Ivoire
label: BODY

text: reporting, which helped to deter any kind of fraud.”
label: BODY

text: Ako sees responsibility on both sides for improving elections. Leaders must listen to the voters.
label: BODY

text: “Young people should draft their own manifestos (or platforms), give them to the politicians and say,
label: BODY

text: “These are our priorities.”
label: BODY

text: And voters have to be responsible in how they use their vote. “Sometimes the population is much
label: BODY

text: more passionate about politics than the issues that relate to them directly. In many capital cities,
label: BODY

text: there’s no access to water and electricity, and the roads are in bad condition. Mobilize to address
label: BODY

text: these specific issues. I think more and more we need to select our leaders based on their manifestos
label: BODY

text: and what they put forward, instead of voting for them because they come from our region or because
label: BODY

text: they are the uncle of my brother or something like that.”
label: BODY

text: Can we stop climate change? The Paris
label: H1

text: summit may be the key.
label: H1

text: It may sound like the latest film noir movie, but it has nothing to do with a police whodunnit. In
label: BODY

text: America, people often informally use the word “cop” to refer to a police officer. But in this case,
label: BODY

text: COP21 is shorthand for the 21st Conference of Parties (COP) to the United Nations Framework
label: BODY

text: Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
label: BODY

text: To put it simply, COP21 is an upcoming summit that brings countries together to solve the problems
label: BODY

text: of global warming and climate change.
label: BODY

text: It all began at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, where the UNFCCC was formed to find
label: BODY

text: ways to “stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere” at low levels to stop further
label: BODY

text: environmental damage. Scientists had found that these emissions from transportation and industry
label: BODY

text: precipitated more rapid climate change — not a good thing.
label: BODY

text: I love Paris in the winter
label: H2

text: COP21 will meet in Paris from November 30 to December 11. It’s going to be big. To date, there are
label: BODY

text: 196 parties to the convention, most of whom will attend. There are also nonmember attendees —
label: BODY

text: observer states and nongovernmental organizations. The parties hope to draft a new international
label: BODY

text: agreement, or protocol, on the climate.
label: BODY

text: To date, at least 150 countries have submitted goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and
label: BODY

text: achieving a low-carbon future through cleaner, more sustainable practices. These goals, called
label: BODY

text: Intended Nationally Determined Contributions, will figure in the the discussions among the parties
label: BODY

text: on how to halt the progress of global warming and climate change. Forty-nine African nations have
label: BODY

text: submitted their goals. Ethiopia, for instance, plans to reduce its emissions by 64 percent below
label: BODY

text: projected business-as-usual emissions by 2030.
label: BODY

text: Climate change is happening faster because of us
label: H2

text: Scientists agree that human activity is largely responsible for the rapid increase in global warming
label: BODY

text: in the past 40 years. There is strong evidence supporting the seriousness of climate change. Drastic
label: BODY

text: changes in weather patterns are occurring: more violent storms, hotter summers and colder winters.
label: BODY

text: If the world continues to warm, sea levels will rise, harming communities located along coastlines.
label: BODY

text: That and drought could create new migration patterns and harm agriculture. Crop yields in some
label: BODY

text: places have diminished in recent years because of exposure to ozone. And warming oceans will
label: BODY

text: affect marine life worldwide in ways that will harm fisheries upon which people depend for food.
label: BODY

text: Droughts are expected to increase in central and southern Africa, along with unprecedented
label: BODY

text: extremes of heat. Studies predict increased annual precipitation in the Horn of Africa and parts of
label: BODY

text: East Africa that will increase the risk of flooding.
label: BODY

text: It will not be just a gab fest
label: H2

text: COP21 will be about cleaner air, healthier people, stronger economies and keeping island nations
label: BODY

text: from disappearing under the sea. The goal: act now to keep global warming below 2 degrees Celsius.
label: BODY

text: To accomplish that, significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions worldwide will have to be
label: BODY

text: made over the next few decades. (Carbon dioxide emissions have reached the highest levels this
label: BODY

text: year, according to NASA, the U.S. space agency.)
label: BODY

text: So what can I do if I’m not in Paris?
label: H2

text: Learn as much as you can about the effects of climate change. NASA’s Vital Signs of the Planet
label: BODY

text: website is a great place to start.
label: BODY

text: Improve your understanding of the negotiations, and get to know the two diplomats (Daniel
label: BODY

text: Reifsnyder of the U.S. and Ahmed Djoghlaf of Algeria) at the center of the agreement.
label: BODY

text: Stay tuned to the U.S. Center at COP21 for live webcasts during the two weeks of the conference.
label: BODY

text: Publish your climate solution on the Climate Solutions Hub.
label: BODY

text: Follow @FactsOnClimate and @US_Center on Twitter, and use hashtags#ActOnClimate and
label: BODY

text: #AskUSCenter to tweet your views.
label: BODY

text: Contact your government officials and urge them to take action now!
label: BODY

text: Take the YALI Network Online Course “Understanding Climate Change.”
label: BODY

text: Facilitate or participate in a YALI Learns event on climate change.
label: BODY

text: #Africa4Her Generates Support for
label: H1

text: Women and Girls: Olivier Nathacia, South
label: H1

text: Africa
label: H1

text: We asked some of the many YALI Network members who in March made an #Africa4Her pledge to
label: BODY

text: invest in women and girls in their community how they have fulfilled that pledge. Here is Olivier
label: BODY

text: Nathacia’s story.
label: BODY

text: I have pledged to invest my time, knowledge and the other resources accessible to me to improve
label: BODY

text: and empower the lives of women and girls within my community.
label: BODY

text: As a young woman residing in South Africa, I noticed that there is a gap regarding support of
label: BODY

text: women’s development and growth. Women are still sidelined, especially those residing in less
label: BODY

text: privileged areas.
label: BODY

text: I also experienced the challenges that most young women and girls come across, especially in the
label: BODY

text: corporate and business arenas. I realized that women are still severely hampered by discrimination,
label: BODY

text: lack of resources and economic opportunities, limited access to decision-making and gender-based
label: BODY

text: violence.
label: BODY

text: I volunteered because I want to be that ripple of change that will close the gap and become part of a
label: BODY

text: generation that makes a difference — a generation that changes obscure obstacles within society
label: BODY

text: about women and girls through entrepreneurship, public innovation and leadership.
label: BODY

text: Olivier Nathacia wants to close
label: BODY

text: the opportunity gap for women
label: BODY

text: and girls
label: BODY

text: I have learned that service is important. More especially when you work with the community, you
label: BODY

text: need to know how to serve people, communicate with them, have time for them, show them that you
label: BODY

text: care. Most of all I learned what it means to be disciplined and be a people’s person.
label: BODY

text: Through volunteering, I learned that leadership is not for the faint-hearted. I have learned what it
label: BODY

text: means to connect and how to build a network that will transform this nation.
label: BODY

text: Most importantly, I learned that women and girls are strong leaders by nature — they thrive in every
label: BODY

text: situation or circumstance. They vouch for justice, yet they need support in order to achieve whatever
label: BODY

text: they want to accomplish in life. They need a platform to share their knowledge, to network and build
label: BODY

text: each other up.
label: BODY

text: This experience through #Africa4Her has made me a creative leader and inspired me to continue
label: BODY

text: with the journey I have embarked on.
label: BODY

text: I can now connect and communicate better. Being amongst women and girls all the time has
label: BODY

text: changed my perception of how women deal and do things from different circumstances of their lives.
label: BODY

text: Service is important when you work with the community.
label: BODY

text: On August 28, 2015, we will once again host an event that focuses on young women and girls. The
label: BODY

text: event will be about the importance of exercising and healthy living.
label: BODY

text: Although it is still hard for me to get all the support I need from government in order to make things
label: BODY

text: happen within my community, I encourage myself to keep going because my passion is assisting
label: BODY

text: young women and girls in every way possible.
label: BODY

text: More than 1,000 YALI Network members made an #Africa4Her pledge. They represent 47 countries,
label: BODY

text: and 54 percent of them are men. If you made an #Africa4Her pledge and would like to share your
label: BODY

text: story, please email us at YALINetwork@state.gov and use the subject line “#Africa4Her.”
label: BODY

text: #YALIGoesGreen 2016: Join us!
label: H1

text: #YALIGoesGreen is a Network-wide initiative to spur climate change awareness and action.
label: BODY

text: In honor of Earth Day (April 22nd), from now through May 15, 2016, YALI Network members who
label: BODY

text: complete one or more of these activities will receive a personalized #YALIGoesGreen badge:
label: BODY

text: Take and teach Understanding Climate Change.
label: BODY

text: Implement green business practices at work, like reducing paper and electricity use.
label: BODY

text: Discuss greening daily habits at home, like reducing water or waste.
label: BODY

text: Organize a community trash pickup day.
label: BODY

text: Host a presentation on climate change in a local school
label: BODY

text: Organize a tree planting event and educate participants on the role of forests in addressing
label: BODY

text: climate change.
label: BODY

text: Organize an event around ocean protection issues and/or conduct a cleanup event of a local
label: BODY

text: outdoor recreational space, waterway, or beach.
label: BODY

text: Talk to local leaders about climate change.
label: BODY

text: Host a recycling drive.
label: BODY

text: Organize a climate awareness walk.
label: BODY

text: Invite experts from local organizations working on environmental issues to speak to your
label: BODY

text: community about climate change.
label: BODY

text: Host an environment-themed film screening and discussion.
label: BODY

text: Work with a local radio program to host a climate-focused show.
label: BODY

text: To earn your badge you must complete the following steps:
label: BODY

text: 1. Select an activity for your event from the list above.
label: BODY

text: 2. Create an event on the YALI Network Face2Face page to advertise your event to the Network.
label: BODY

text: 3. After your event is complete post pictures in Face2Face to let everyone know how it went.
label: BODY

text: 4. Tell us about your event here by May 15, 2016 to get your personalized badge!
label: BODY

text: For tips on how to facilitate a #YALIGoesGreen or #YALILearns event visit yali.state.gov/learns.
label: BODY

text: Let’s take action and help spread the word today!
label: BODY

text: Hosting a #YALIGoesGreen event
label: H3

text: Want some ideas on how to facilitate and engage and audience during your #YALIGoesGreen event?
label: BODY

text: Download the event facilitation guide (PDF) with a complete lesson plan to use along with
label: BODY

text: this PowerPoint presentation (PPTX).
label: BODY

text: Please remember that all #YALILearns and #YALIGoesGreen events are organized on the basis of
label: BODY

text: educating your community with shared YALI Network resources. You should never charge a fee
label: BODY

text: for a YALI Network event, and remind others if you see this occuring.
label: BODY

text: Promoting a #YALIGoesGreen event
label: H3

text: Earth Day 2016 Postcard

text: More on Climate Change
label: H2

text: YALI Goes Green and Accepts the Earth Day Call to Action
label: BODY

text: April 22, 2016, is a good day for Africa. Here’s why:
label: BODY

text: The goal is to plant 7.8 billion trees by 2020. Can you help?
label: BODY

text: Online learning spurs offline climate action
label: BODY

text: It Started with a Challenge: One Month, 1,000 Trees
label: BODY

text: #YALICHAT: Wanjira Mathai Connects
label: H1

text: with the YALI Network on Climate Change
label: H1

text: From November 17 to 19, YALI Network Online Course instructor and director of wPOWER hub
label: BODY

text: Wanjira Mathai held a YALICHAT to answer questions from YALI Network members. One of the
label: BODY

text: common themes addressed throughout the chat was how individual citizens can make an impact for
label: BODY

text: good in their communities.
label: BODY

text: “Raising public awareness about the climate crisis and giving local communities practical actions
label: BODY

text: they can take to mitigate and adapt is crucial — water harvesting, food security, tree planting are
label: BODY

text: but a few,” Mathai says. “Young people should be encouraged to plant trees in school, at home, at
label: BODY

text: church. We want to create a culture of planting trees so that we do it because we know it is
label: BODY

text: important for us. A national tree planting week would be a great idea; ideally, when schools are
label: BODY

text: closed (say around Easter). Public tree planting is great in that it will build solidarity nationwide.
label: BODY

text: Tree planting is an everyday affair: When you are happy, plant a tree!”
label: BODY

text: One of the main concerns for YALI Network members was the role the government plays in
label: BODY

text: addressing the problem at hand: While citizens of each country can do their part, governments
label: BODY

text: should promote clean energy solutions and encourage industries to do the same.
label: BODY

text: “What  many  governments  want  to  believe  is  that  economic  growth  and  clean  energy  are
label: BODY

text: incompatible,” Mathai says. “They are compatible. In fact, some of the world’s economic leaders are
label: BODY

text: prioritizing clean energy because they know it will be good for people, planet and profit — the triple
label: BODY

text: bottom line.”
label: BODY

text: Governments are beginning to implement solutions to improve air quality. New Delhi, for example, is
label: BODY

text: creating  an  organized  mass  transit  system  to  encourage  people  to  use  public  transit  more
label: BODY

text: frequently.
label: BODY

text: “I was impressed when I visited New Delhi recently and heard that the government just got tough on
label: BODY

text: emissions,” Mathai says. “Some of the interventions they introduced included public awareness
label: BODY

text: campaigns around health impacts of air pollution and pollution checks to ensure that only road-
label: BODY

text: worthy vehicles are on their roads.”
label: BODY

text: Network members were particularly interested in deforestation. According to Mathai, at a practical
label: BODY

text: level, destroying forests has short-term benefits but serious long-term consequences.
label: BODY

text: “We have to begin to see all these impacts from a systems perspective. When we destroy our forests
label: BODY

text: and landscapes, we destroy their ability to support life and replenish rivers and underground
label: BODY

text: aquifers. We are told by the U.N. that we need a forest cover minimum of 10 percent for sustainable
label: BODY

text: development. Most of our countries have decimated our forests with little or no reforestation taking
label: BODY

text: place. The function these forests used to play is stopped, and so the services it provided cease. So
label: BODY

text: floods and famines (which become droughts) have become more frequent.”
label: BODY

text: In addition to discussing the role the government plays, another concern addressed in the chat
label: BODY

text: centered around the issue of clean water. According to Voice of America’s Straight Talk Africa, 350
label: BODY

text: million to 600 million people in Africa are projected to be exposed to water stress due to climate
label: BODY

text: change.
label: BODY

text: “For most of our countries, restoring the degraded landscapes and riverine forests with indigenous
label: BODY

text: vegetation is an important investment,” Mathai says. “In the meantime, we must work on ways of
label: BODY

text: harvesting water when it rains. We must find ways to harvest the water from our roofs, particularly
label: BODY

text: in agricultural areas where it can be used during the dry season, and also learn techniques for in
label: BODY

text: situ water harvesting. There is a lot we can learn from counties like Israel and projects like we have
label: BODY

text: seen in Ethiopia (watch “Ethiopia Rising”) where terraces, check dams, gabions and many other
label: BODY

text: water harvesting techniques have been employed in addition to tree planting and farmer-managed
label: BODY

text: natural regeneration of trees.”
label: BODY

text: We protect what we care about. In order for action to be taken, something has to be at stake. Here is
label: BODY

text: some advice straight from Mathai to the YALI Network on how to speak to your community about
label: BODY

text: climate change:
label: BODY

text: “The best way to explain climate change to others is to engage them in activities that demonstrate
label: BODY

text: what it means and also take them to beautiful places that they might experience environmental
label: BODY

text: beauty. You know the saying: “We protect what we love.”
label: BODY

text: 5 tips for building a successful advocacy
label: H1

text: campaign
label: H1

text: Join #YALIGoesGreen this month. Learn how to get involved at yali.state.gov/climate
label: BODY

text: Are you trying to get the word out — either for a candidate or a cause you feel passionate about?
label: BODY

text: Social media is great, but when online supporters turn into offline volunteers, your advocacy
label: BODY

text: campaign reaches a new level.
label: BODY

text: Aisha Satterwhite of Blue State Digital, a leading digital-strategy agency, said, “Every group thinks
label: BODY

text: its problems are different, but they’re often the same.” She said often a group uses conflicting
label: BODY

text: messages for the same campaign, or a message that is so vague it won’t mean anything to people.
label: BODY

text: These five tips will help you match your message to your intended audience and motivate them to
label: BODY

text: get off the sidelines for your cause.
label: BODY

text: Know how your audience communicates
label: H2

text: Do the people you’re trying to reach respond to email? SMS texts? Will radio, print and other
label: BODY

text: traditional media be most effective? For many advocacy campaigns, time spent knocking on doors
label: BODY

text: produces better results than a hundred emails.
label: BODY

text: Macala  Wright,  a  digital  marketing  strategist,  suggests  nonprofits  with  limited  budgets  take
label: BODY

text: advantage of free resources to learn about online audiences. For instance, Google Analytics can tell
label: BODY

text: you what country visitors to your website are from, where on your site they’re going and what
label: BODY

text: devices (mobile, desktop, tablet) they’re using. “That’s information any organization can use to make
label: BODY

text: informed decisions on how they’re messaging,” Wright said.
label: BODY

text: Figure out your messaging strategy
label: H2

text: A good advocacy campaign has a core message, Wright said, and how you present that message
label: BODY

text: determines how far it spreads. “There are three good ways to make your message appealing: humor,
label: BODY

text: inspiration and enlightened education,” Wright said. “People share things that make them happy or
label: BODY

text: make them want to learn more.”
label: BODY

text: Spur your audience to act
label: H2

text: Know what it is you want your audience to do, and make sure the audience knows it too. Perhaps it
label: BODY

text: is as simple as sharing your post on Facebook. Sign a petition? Attend a meeting? Vote for a
label: BODY

text: candidate? If you’re asking for donations, Satterwhite advises that you “think what it would take for
label: BODY

text: you to actually take money out of your pocket and give it to someone. How would you want them to
label: BODY

text: approach you?”
label: BODY

text: Move people toward engagement
label: H2

text: How engaged is your audience? This chart shows how influence can be increased by gradually
label: BODY

text: increasing engagement. (Source: Blue State Digital, State Dept.)
label: BODY

text: Convincing someone to “like” your organization’s page on Facebook is easy; convincing him or her
label: BODY

text: to host an event at home to raise funds for your organization is hard. These are examples of the
label: BODY

text: bottom and top rungs of what media strategists call the ladder of engagement. By gradually asking
label: BODY

text: more of your audience as it engages with you — to opt in for email updates, to make a small
label: BODY

text: donation, to attend a live event, to knock on doors for your cause — you can convert an online
label: BODY

text: bystander into an enthusiastic worker for your cause.
label: BODY

text: Test your messages
label: H2

text: Both Satterwhite and Wright stress the importance of trying different approaches and learning from
label: BODY

text: the results. For a social media posting, Wright advises trying the same message starting off with a
label: BODY

text: question (“Have you thought about where your food comes from?”) and then again with a compelling
label: BODY

text: fact (“Processed foods make up 70 percent of your community’s diet.”)
label: BODY

text: “Whatever has better traction in terms of share, engagement and reach,” said Wright, is the
label: BODY

text: approach to use. But she said you must always try new things, because digital behaviors move very
label: BODY

text: rapidly.”
label: BODY
